title-group.article-title: Importance of Technical Preparation of Intraarterial Shunts to Prevent Iatrogenic Arterial Injury During Urgent Procedures

abstract.p: Although intraarterial shunting during carotid endarterectomy is a well-defined practice, its use remains controversial. Complication rates associated with shunt placement remain low, but may be underreported. When complications secondary to routine intraarterial shunting occur, they can cause significant morbidity or even mortality, emphasizing the importance of meticulous technique to prevent adverse outcomes. We report a case of internal carotid artery dissection and pseuedoaneurysm due to the technical failure of a safety device of an intraarterial shunt used during carotid endarterectomy.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Intraarterial shunting during carotid endarterectomy is a well-described practice; however, its use remains controversial. 1,2,3 Some surgeons utilize shunts routinely during repair, while others either employ selective shunting or no shunting at all. Proponents of shunting maintain that the complications from shunt use are rare, and that functioning shunts minimize the risk of cerebral hypoperfusion. 4 Complications of intraarterial carotid shunt placement include atheromatous or air embolization through the shunt itself, carotid dissection with possible embolization or thrombosis, acute occlusion of the shunt, and aneurysm at the site of shunt placement. However, some argue that the complications of shunt use are underreported. 1,5,6 We report a case of internal carotid artery dissection and pseudoaneurysm resulting from overinflation of the anchoring balloon due to preparation failure of a safety device.

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: An 84-year-old highly functional woman with a history of severe hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, peripheral artery disease, and lower extremity bypass surgery underwent several months of left carotid artery surveillance for moderate to severe (50%-69%) asymptomatic disease. Despite aggressive medical optimization of her risk factors, the stenosis worsened to greater than 80% by carotid duplex ultrasound and computed tomography (CT) angiography. Her vessel calcification and bovine aortic arch anatomy made a carotid angioplasty and stent procedure unsafe and relatively contraindicated.

She was offered a left carotid endarterectomy with patch closure and intraoperative electroencephalogram (EEG) monitoring. Following 1 minute of internal carotid clamping, severe, irreversible EEG changes with electrical flat-line of the left hemisphere were reported and a Pruitt-Inahara shunt with inline Doppler (Implantable Devices, Pinellas Park, Florida) was readied for placement to confirm flow. Relatively easy distal placement with blood return was observed and the balloon was inflated according to the manufacturer’s instructions for use. Due to a large internal carotid artery diameter, some retrograde bleeding was noted from the lumen and the distal balloon was filled to its maximum capacity. Although hemostasis was achieved, concern was established regarding the lack of inflation of the safety balloon. Evaluation revealed that the transparent silicone sleeve was not advanced to expose the safety balloon and render it functional. Proximal shunt limb placement was achieved uneventfully, however flow was absent, as evidenced by lack of Doppler signal through the shunt. A second, similar shunt was placed with the same result. Finally, a Sundt shunt (Integra, Plainsboro, New Jersey) was prepared and advanced intracranially. This demonstrated an audible Doppler signal confirming arterial flow and normalization of EEG waveform activity.

The endarterectomy and patch closure was performed without incident. Further instrumentation, including arterial duplex or completion arteriography was not performed at this time. An error in judgment allowed the patient to be awoken in the operating room and a dense right hemiparesis and aphasia was observed. The perioperative plan included immediate transfer to CT scan to define the arterial anatomy, while a dedicated neurointerventional radiology suite was readied for the patient following reintubation.

The CT scan delineated a dissecting pseudoaneurysm of the internal carotid artery at the base of the skull, which was also apparent on initial angiography (Figure 1). With technical difficulty, a 0.014-in wire was advanced across the lesion of the damaged artery, allowing for the placement of a 6 mm × 10 cm covered stent graft (Viabahn, Gore, Flagstaff, Arizona). A second nitinol self-expanding stent, 5 mm × 20 mm (Zilver, Cook Medical, Bloomington, Indiana) was placed distally as well for completion of the repair (Figure 2). She was kept heparinized and intubated until the next morning when her neurological status was able to be assessed and was stable. She regained some right-sided upper extremity and lower extremity function and an improvement in her speech. Unrelated to the circumstances at hand, the patient’s family withdrew medical care following the development of rhabdomyolysis and acute renal failure stemming from an acutely occluded lower extremity bypass graft, despite a progressive improvement in the patient’s neurological status.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The patient’s unfortunate outcome and extensive root-cause analysis shed light on the importance of device preparation when used urgently. Arterial shunts have been instrumental in carotid surgery following recent stroke or when intracranial cross-filling is not sufficient to maintain a baseline EEG. 1,7,8 The overwhelming concerns of shunt use have focused on thrombosis and dislodgment during transport, though reports of complications in the literature are few. 5,6,9,10 To our knowledge, this is the first report of a flow-limiting dissection and pseudoaneurysm using a shunt with balloons designed for hemostasis and positioning.

Although the shunt used was designed with an “overfill” safety balloon for the distal anchor, operator error in making certain that the silicone sleeve was advanced prior to placement did not occur (Figure 3). The authors strongly support that in addition to proper operating room personnel training, one of many simple changes be made by the manufacturers of all such shunts. The silicone sleeve could be in the “open” or advanced position when the device is packaged, obviating the need to activate the safety feature. Additionally, a detachable label could be placed for easy identification on the sleeve, or the sleeve could be demarcated with a colored silicone for easy identification.
